\( \def\curl#1{\text{curl }#1} \def\bracket#1{\left({#1}\right)} \def\sbracket#1{\left[{#1}\right]} %square bracket \def\cbracket#1{\left\{{#1}\right\}} %curly bracket \def\Lim_#1{{\lim\limits_{#1}}} \def\limit{{\lim\limits_{n \to \infty}}} \def\dsum{{\displaystyle \sum}} \def\Sum_#1^#2{{\sum\limits_{#1}^#2}} \def\summ{\sum\limits_{n=0}^{\infty}} \def\R{{\mathbb R}} \def\N{{\mathbb N}} \def\fQ{{\mathcal{Q}}} \def\riemannR{{\mathscr{R}}} \def\ep{\varepsilon} \def\d{\displaystyle} \def\grad{\nabla} \def\q{q} \def\mod#1{\left | {#1} \right |} \def\abs#1{\left | {#1} \right |} \def\crossProduct#1{\left\|\begin{array}{ccc} #1 \end{array}\right\|} \newcommand{\partialwrt}[2][]{\frac{\partial {#1}}{\partial {#2}}} \newcommand{\dpartialwrt}[2][]{\dfrac{\partial {#1}}{\partial {#2}}} \def\upint{\mkern3mu\overline{\vphantom{\intop}\mkern7mu}\mkern-20mu\int} \def\lowint{\mkern3mu\underline{\vphantom{\intop}\mkern7mu}\mkern-10mu\int} \def\lowsup_#1{_{{\lower{0.3em}{#1}}}} \)
  • Home
  • analysis
  • ch07
  • theorems
  • theorem-7-08.html

The sequence of functions $\{f_n\}$, defined on $E$, converges uniformly on $E$ if and only if for every $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that $m \geq N, n\geq N, x \in E$ implies $\mod{f_n(x)-f_m(x)} \leq \varepsilon$

Suppose $\{f_n\}$ converges uniformly on $E$.

Let $\ep > 0$ and $f$ be the limit function.

Then there exists an integer $N$ such that $n\geq N, x \in E$ implies $\abs{f_n(x)-f(x)} \leq \frac{\varepsilon}{2}$
$$\abs{f_n(x)-f_m(x)} = \abs{f_n(x)-f(x)+f(x)-f_m(x)} \leq \abs{f_n(x)-f(x)} + \abs{f_m(x)-f(x)} $$ $$\begin{align*} n\geq N, x \in E \ \text{ implies } \abs{f_n(x)-f(x)} &\leq \frac{\ep}{2}\\ m\geq N, x \in E \ \text{ implies } \abs{f_m(x)-f(x)} &\leq \frac{\ep}{2}\\ \mbox{Hence } n\geq N, m \geq N, x \in E \ \text{ implies } \abs{f_n(x)-f_m(x)} &\leq \abs{f_n(x)-f(x)} + \abs{f_m(x)-f(x)}\\ &\leq \frac{\varepsilon}{2} + \frac{\varepsilon}{2} = \varepsilon \end{align*}$$

Therefore there exists an integer $N$ such that $n\geq N, m \geq N, x \in E$ implies $\abs{f_n(x)-f_m(x)} \leq \varepsilon$

Now suppose that for every $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that $$m \geq N, n\geq N, x \in E \mbox{ implies } \mod{f_n(x)-f_m(x)} \leq \varepsilon \tag{1}$$

Then, by 3.11, for every $x$, the sequence $\{f_n(x)\}$ converges to the limit, say $f(x)$. Thus $f_n \to f$ pointwise. We need to prove $f_n \to f$ uniformly.

Let $\varepsilon > 0$ be given. Choose an integer $N$ such that (1) holds.

As $m \to \infty$, $f_m(x) \to f(x)$

Hence fixing $n$ and letting $m \to \infty$ in (1) gives $n\geq N, x \in E$ implies $\mod{f_n(x)-f(x)} \leq \varepsilon$

Therefore $\{f_n\}$ converges uniformly on $E$.

The proof is completed.
